conclusion: The Stirling cycle consists of four processes: A→B: Isothermal expansion, B→C: Adiabatic expansion, C→D: Isothermal compression, D→A: Adiabatic compression.
In an isothermal process, the temperature of the gas remains constant. This means that the average kinetic energy of the gas molecules is constant.
The rate distribution curve of the gas molecules is determined by the temperature. Since the temperature is constant in the isothermal processes, the rate distribution curve will not change.
In an adiabatic process, there is no heat exchange with the surroundings. The internal energy of the gas changes due to work done on or by the gas.
The temperature of the gas will change in an adiabatic process. For an ideal gas, the temperature will increase during an adiabatic compression and decrease during an adiabatic expansion.
The rate distribution curve of the gas molecules is sensitive to the temperature. Therefore, if the temperature changes during the adiabatic processes, the rate distribution curve will change.

premise: The process D→A is an adiabatic compression.
conclusion: Since it is an adiabatic process, the temperature of the gas will increase.

premise: An increase in temperature will lead to a change in the rate distribution curve of the gas molecules.
conclusion: The higher temperature will result in a broader and more spread-out rate distribution curve compared to the lower temperature.

premise: The rate distribution curve of the gas molecules will change during the process D→A because the temperature increases during this adiabatic compression.
conclusion: Therefore, the rate distribution curve of the gas molecule does change during the process D to A.
